awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Supports as steric and electronic modifiers of catalysis at single atom metal active sites
awd_abstract_narration:
1554112 
Christopher, Phillip

Promoting Catalytic Reactions Via Isolated Metal Atoms

Supported metal catalysts, especially those utilizing expensive noble metals such as rhodium (Rh), are often most effectively utilized when the noble metal is dispersed as extremely small particles - and in the limit as isolated metal atoms.  This study examines at a fundamental level how interactions between the supporting oxide material and the active noble metal can be engineered to control the stability and activity of isolated Rh atoms.  Insights from the work will be used to design catalysts with high selectivity in propylene hydroformylation - an important industrial reaction currently operated under homogeneous liquid-phase catalytic conditions.  A heterogeneous, gas-phase analog - as sought here - would offer a lower cost, environmentally friendly alternative.  Additionally, the research will provide opportunities for a broadly diverse student body at UC Riverside to develop both the analytical and communication skills needed for successful technical careers.

The project focuses on controlling the selectivity, reactivity, and stability of isolated metal atom catalysts by varying the oxide support and by functionalizing the support with organosilane moieties in ways that create electronic and steric structures that replicate those of single-metal-atom homogeneous catalysts.  Central to the study are a host of techniques involving synthesis, in-situ catalyst transformations, and analytical methods that will be utilized to create, confirm, and characterize the isolated atom sites and control their activity and stability.  Fundamental experiments will be carried out using probe molecule spectroscopy, probe reaction kinetics, in-situ spectroscopy and microscopy, and density functional theory calculations.  While the immediate focus will be on propylene hydroformylation, the associated fundamental understanding will benefit society through the design of heterogeneous catalytic processes that are more energy and environmentally friendly than homogeneous processes.  The highly multidisciplinary nature of the project will provide plentiful opportunities for students at this Hispanic serving institution to develop skills in presenting technical information based on carefully reasoned and structured scientific arguments.

por.por_cntn:
Many industrial chemical reactions require solid-state catalysts containing active precious metals (e.g. Pt, Rh). The high cost and scarcity of precious metals necessitate efficient use. An emerging approach is stabilizing precious metals as single atoms so that every atom is exposed to reactants and available to perform catalysis. When this project started there was debate on the reactivity, coordination environment, and spectroscopic signatures of ?single atom? catalysts. To address this, we designed a catalyst architecture that stabilized single metal atoms, enabling measurements of their properties and reactivity. While most in the field were increasing metal loadings in single atom catalysts, we decreased the metal loading and used small oxide nanoparticle supports, such that each support particle would contain statistically ~ 1 metal atom or less. 

Focusing on Pt single atoms on reducible oxide supports (TiO2 and CeO2) and varying Pt loading above and below ~1 Pt atom per support particle, changes in infrared spectra of adsorbed CO were observed, and assignments of CO bound to single Pt atoms were made. The stretching frequency of CO bound to Pt single atoms is similar to PtOx clusters, while CO binds to the two Pt structures with different strength. Thus, the binding energy and vibrational frequency of probe molecules are necessary to differentiate clusters and single atoms. Reactivity assignments were made for Pt single atoms on TiO2 for CO oxidation and m-cresol hydrodeoxygenation, as well as Pt single atoms on CeO2 for CO oxidation. The results highlight that reactivity measurements are often the most sensitive tool for discriminating the existence of single atoms versus metal clusters.

By correlating the CO stretching band frequency and binding energy to theory, an active site structure was proposed, where Pt2+ resided in a distorted square planar structure at TiO2 step edges. In-situ spectroscopy, microscopy, and theory were used understand how Pt single atoms restructure in different conditions: (1) Pt4+ replaces Ti4+ in TiO2 under oxidizing conditions, (2) adopts a square planar Pt2+ structure following mild reduction in H2, and (3) near neutral Pt becomes mobile as PtOH species under harsh reducing conditions. 

Pt single atoms on CeO2 were found to reside in square planar structures on (100) microfacets. The more stable coordination for Pt on CeO2, as compared to TiO2, results in Pt/CeO2 single atom catalysts being less reactive and the Pt species being less reducible. Thus, Pt local coordination environment dictates reactivity, rather than the inherent support properties. 

The catalyst architecture involving isolation of single atoms on small oxide domains motivated many subsequent studies and the resulting spectroscopic assignments serve as benchmarks for the field. 

Significant focus was also given to Rh atoms on 5 nm Al2O3 supports for alkene hydroformylation to aldehydes (e.g. ethylene to propanal). Hydroformylation is performed industrially using homogeneous Rh+1 catalysts ? similar to Rh gem dicarbonyls, Rh+1(CO)2, that form on Al2O3 during hydroformylation. The rate of ethylene hydroformylation on Rh single atoms on Al2O3 is 5-6 orders of magnitude lower than for homogeneous Rh complexes and the selectivity is 20-30% to the aldehyde (the remainder is to the alkane) where homogeneous Rh complexes exhibit quantitative selectivity. 

Rh/Al2O3 catalysts were modified with alkyl phosphonic acids (PA) at varying PA coverage with varying alkyl chain tail length from 1 (methyl, MPA) to 16 (hexadecyl, HDPA) to influence the reactivity. The addition of MPA decreased the sintering rate of Rh single atoms, suggesting that Rh(CO)2 is mobile on Al2O3 and that MPA inhibits the mobility. PA modification of Rh/Al2O3 promoted CO desorption rates from Rh and ethylene hydroformylation rates and selectivity. HDPA modification caused a ~120 K decrease in the temperature of CO desorption from Rh(CO)2, and ~ 1000x enhancement in propanal formation rates on Rh, as compared to Rh/Al2O3. Eyring analyses showed that PA modification only influences the apparent activation entropies of CO desorption and hydroformylation. Quantitative correlation between changes in the activation entropy of these two reactions was observed.

These results suggest that Rh(CO)2 has entropy due to mobility on the support and that Rh(CO)2 has to be constrained for CO desorption to occur. PAs promote Rh reactivity by constraining its mobility and increasing the attempt frequency for CO desorption. This introduces a new idea for heterogeneous catalysts: engineering active site entropy for mobile active sites can be used to control catalytic performance.

This project impacted the education and professional development of graduate and undergraduate students. Students were trained in fundamental catalytic phenomena, including synthesis, characterization, reactivity evaluation, structural changes, and mechanistic analysis of supported metal catalysts. Students combined experiments and theory, which is a unique approach that provides a holistic view of catalytic science, and gained experience working at synchrotron beamlines. Students were trained in writing and presentation of scientific results, and a significant amount of new content was added to undergraduate courses based on the findings of this project.
